Description: Torso of terracotta figure of Aphrodite. The torso and upper legs of Aphrodite, modelled in the round, naked except for drapery that falls from the left shoulder. She stands leaning forward slightly, and inclined even more so to her right, producing a distinct crease at waist level on her right side. The breasts are not large, and a tiny twist of clay in the pubic area must be fortuitous on a female body: it does not represent male genitals and we do not have Hermaphrodite here. The buttocks are well rendered. Solid; probably hand-modelled. Micaceous brown Nile silt, with overall traces of a white dressing; some yellow paint survives on the flesh areas.
Curator's comments: BM Terracotta IV The pose is that of a variant of Aphrodite loosening her sandal, and can be compared with LIMC ii: Aphrodite 475, 477 and 479: none of these has long hair or drapery.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3354)
Condition: The head and both arms are lost and the legs are broken away at the knees; the drapery on the left side is damaged. Breaks above the shoulders and some ridges on the right shoulder just in front of the break may show that tresses of long hair have been lost.
